newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine gas, electric prices to be flat in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine gas, electric prices to be flat in 1997.

text.p: The Ukrainian government has abandoned its plan to raise natural gas and electricity prices for residential customers in 1997, Prime Minister Pavlo Lazarenko said on Monday.
"Despite the tough economic situation facing Ukraine today, gas and electricity prices will not go up," he said during a visit to the eastern industrial city of Dnipropetrovsk.
The International Monetary Fund, negotiating the terms of a three-year, $2.5-3.0 billion Extended Fund Facility with Kiev, wants to see residents pay full energy costs next year.
Ukrainians currently pay only 80 percent of energy costs.
Lazarenko forecast government subsidies to residential gas consumers would total $1.12 billion for 1996, and said consumer debt to Ukrainian utilities was 1.4 billion hryvnia.
But the prime minister also said Ukraine planned to take steps to overhaul its energy sector next year, including reducing the use of barter as payment by consumers.
He said Ukraine would need $620 million next year to purchase fuel from Russia for its 14 operating nuclear stations.
